title.narrative: Dynamique spatio-temporelle et élaboration d'un modèle de réglementation de la transhumance du bétail sur le plateau de Mahafaly (Madagascar)
Spatial-Temporal Dynamics and Development of a Model for the Regulation of Livestock Transhumance in the Mahafaly Plateau, Southwest Madagascar

description.narrative:
Madagascar's southwestern region is one of the poorest in the country. The Tsimanampetsotsa National Park covers a large part the region and features unique biodiversity. Its resources are crucial for the surrounding communities, but they are also under increasing pressure by humans. Communities living around the park comprise a mixture of subsistence farmers and transhumance (seasonal movers) pastoralists, who move with their livestock between summer and winter pastures. In the past, relations between the two groups were managed largely through family ties and well-defined, traditional pathways for moving livestock.
Several factors have changed this situation and created important development challenges. This research project aims to address those challenges by reducing conflict among communities through better natural resources management and better local livestock governance across Madagascar's Mahafaly Plateau.
Some of the challenges seen over the past two decades include: -Increasingly recurrent droughts have deepened poverty and food insecurity. They have forced pastoralist groups to change their traditional transhumance routes. They enter into the park boundaries illegally and interact with communities beyond their traditional ties. There is little information about the numbers of pastoralists and livestock involved.
-Madagascar's political instability since 2009 has led to reduced public services, including control bodies. This, in turn, has led to the communities feeling increasingly marginalized and insecure. There have been more episodes of armed bands attacking farmers and pastoralists, livestock thefts, and unregulated killing of protected species. These armed bands are often formed by former pastoralists who have lost their livestock due to droughts, or have been denied access to or transit through particular areas. The net result is increased conflict between farmers and pastoralists. Thefts and unregulated land occupation have also contributed to communities' food insecurity around the park.
Through this effort, the project team aims to: -enhance understanding of livestock dynamics across the Mahafaly Plateau; -shed light on the approaches needed to reduce social instability and ensure better local management of natural resources; -develop a regulatory system for transhumance that is adapted to the changing dynamics; and, -help communities accept and apply effective regulatory systems by integrating them into formal legislation.
